026/**
027 * A text generator for producing sentences and/or words in nonsense languages that fit a theme. This does not use an
028 * existing word list as a basis for its output, so it may or may not produce existing words occasionally, but you can
029 * safely assume it won't generate a meaningful sentence except in the absolute unlikeliest of cases.
030 * <br>
031 * This supports a lot of language styles in predefined constants. There's a registry of these constants in
032 * {@link #registered} and their names in {@link #registeredNames}, plus the languages that would make sense for
033 * real-world cultures to use (and all use the Latin alphabet, so they can be swapped around) are in
034 * {@link #romanizedHumanLanguages}. You can make a new language with a constructor, but it's pretty time-consuming; the
035 * recommended ways are generating a random language with {@link #randomLanguage(long)} (when you don't care too much
036 * about exactly how it should sound), or blending two or more languages with {@link #mixAll(Object...)} or
037 * {@link #mix(double, FakeLanguageGen, double, Object...)} (when you have a sound in mind that isn't quite met by an
038 * existing language).
039 * <br>
040 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 11/29/2015.
041 * @see NaturalLanguageCipher NaturalLanguageCipher uses a FakeLanguageGen to reversibly translate English text to nonsense.
042 * @see Thesaurus Thesaurus uses this class a lot to generate things like plant names and the titles of nations.
043 */
044public class FakeLanguageGen implements Serializable {
045    private static final long serialVersionUID = -2396642435461186352L;
046    public final String[] openingVowels, midVowels, openingConsonants, midConsonants, closingConsonants,
047            vowelSplitters, closingSyllables;
048    public final boolean clean;
049    public final double[] syllableFrequencies;
050    protected final double totalSyllableFrequency;
051    public final double syllableBias;
052    public final double vowelStartFrequency, vowelEndFrequency, vowelSplitFrequency, syllableEndFrequency;
053    public final Pattern[] sanityChecks;
054    public final ArrayList<Modifier> modifiers;
055    public static final GWTRNG srng = new GWTRNG();
056    private static final OrderedMap<String, FakeLanguageGen> registry = new OrderedMap<>(64, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
057    protected String summary;
058    protected String name = "Nameless Language";
059    private static final transient StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(20);
060    private static final transient StringBuilder ender = new StringBuilder(12);
061    private static final transient StringBuilder ssb = new StringBuilder(80);
062    /**
063     * A pattern String that will match any vowel FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box, including Latin, Greek,
064     * and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
065     */
066    public static final String anyVowel = "[àáâãäåæāăǎąǻǽaèéêëēĕėęěeìíîïĩīĭįǐıiòóôõöøōŏőǒœǿoùúûüũūŭůǔűųuýÿŷỳyαοειυωаеёийоуъыэюя]",
067    /**
068     * A pattern String that will match one or more of any vowels FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box, including
069     * Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in 
070     * {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
071     */
072    anyVowelCluster = anyVowel + '+',
073    /**
074     * A pattern String that will match any consonant FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box, including Latin,
075     * Greek, and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in
076     * {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
077     */
078    anyConsonant = "[bcçćĉċčdþðďđfgĝğġģhĥħjĵȷkķlĺļľŀłmnñńņňŋpqrŕŗřsśŝşšștţťțvwŵẁẃẅxyýÿŷỳzźżžρσζτκχνθμπψβλγφξςбвгдклпрстфхцжмнзчшщ]",
079    /**
080     * A pattern String that will match one or more of any consonants FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box,
081     * including Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in
082     * {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
083     */
084    anyConsonantCluster = anyConsonant + '+';
085    protected static final Pattern repeats = Pattern.compile("(.)\\1+"),
086            vowelClusters = Pattern.compile(anyVowelCluster, REFlags.IGNORE_CASE | REFlags.UNICODE),
087            consonantClusters = Pattern.compile(anyConsonantCluster, REFlags.IGNORE_CASE | REFlags.UNICODE);

099            vulgarChecks = new Pattern[]
100            {
101                    //17 is REFlags.UNICODE | REFlags.IGNORE_CASE
102                    Pattern.compile("[sξζzkкκcсς][hнlι].{1,3}[dtтτΓг]", 17),
103                    Pattern.compile("(?:(?:[pрρ][hн])|[fd]).{1,3}[kкκcсςxхжχq]", 17), // lots of these end in a 'k' sound, huh
104                    Pattern.compile("[kкκcсςСQq][uμυνvhн]{1,3}[kкκcсςxхжχqmм]", 17),
105                    Pattern.compile("[bъыбвβЪЫБ].?[iτιyуλγУ].?[cсς]", 17),
106                    Pattern.compile("[hн][^aаαΛeезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУ][^aаαΛeезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУ]?[rяΓ]", 17),
107                    Pattern.compile("[tтτΓгcсς][iτιyуλγУ][tтτΓг]+$", 17),
108                    Pattern.compile("(?:(?:[pрρ][hн])|f)[aаαΛhн]{1,}[rяΓ][tтτΓг]", 17),
109                    Pattern.compile("[Ssξζzcсς][hн][iτιyуλγУ].?[sξζzcсς]", 17),
110                    Pattern.compile("[aаαΛ][nи][aаαΛeезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУoоюσοuμυνv]{1,2}[Ssξlιζz]", 17),
111                    Pattern.compile("[aаαΛ]([sξζz]{2})", 17),
112                    Pattern.compile("[kкκcсςСQq][hн]?[uμυνv]([hн]?)[nи]+[tтτΓг]", 17),
113                    Pattern.compile("[nиfvν]..?[jg]", 17), // might as well remove two possible slurs and a body part with one check
114                    Pattern.compile("[pрρ](?:(?:([eезξεЗΣoоюσοuμυνv])\\1)|(?:[eезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУuμυνv]+[sξζz]))", 17), // the grab bag of juvenile words
115                    Pattern.compile("[mм][hнwψшщ]?..?[rяΓ].?d", 17), // should pick up the #1 obscenity from Spanish and French
116                    Pattern.compile("[g][hн]?[aаαАΑΛeеёзξεЕЁЗΕΣ][yуλγУeеёзξεЕЁЗΕΣ]", 17), // could be inappropriate for random text
117                    Pattern.compile("[wψшщuμυνv](?:[hн]?)[aаαΛeеёзξεЗΕΣoоюσοuμυνv](?:[nи]+)[gkкκcсςxхжχq]", 17)

410    /*
411     * Removes accented characters from a string; if the "base" characters are non-English anyway then the result won't
412     * be an ASCII string, but otherwise it probably will be.
413     * <br>
414     * Credit to user hashable from http://stackoverflow.com/a/1215117
415     *
416     * @param str a string that may contain accented characters
417     * @return a string with all accented characters replaced with their (possibly ASCII) counterparts
418     *
419    public String removeAccents(String str) {
420        String alteredString = Normalizer.normalize(str, Normalizer.Form.NFD);
421        alteredString = diacritics.matcher(alteredString).replaceAll("");
422        alteredString = alteredString.replace('æ', 'a');
423        alteredString = alteredString.replace('œ', 'o');
424        alteredString = alteredString.replace('Æ', 'A');
425        alteredString = alteredString.replace('Œ', 'O');
426        return alteredString;
427    }*/
428
429    /**
430     * Removes accented Latin-script characters from a string; if the "base" characters are non-English anyway then the
431     * result won't be an ASCII string, but otherwise it probably will be.
432     *
433     * @param str a string that may contain accented Latin-script characters
434     * @return a string with all accented characters replaced with their (possibly ASCII) counterparts
435     */
436    public static CharSequence removeAccents(CharSequence str) {
437        CharSequence alteredString = str;
438        for (int i = 0; i < accentFinders.length; i++) {
439            alteredString = accentFinders[i].replace(alteredString);
440        }
441        return alteredString;
442    }
443
444    private FakeLanguageGen register(String languageName) {
445        summary = registry.size() + "@1";
446        registry.put(languageName,this);
447        name = languageName;
448        return copy();
449    }
450
451    private FakeLanguageGen summarize(String brief) {
452        summary = brief;
453        return this;
454    }

800    /**
801     * Swahili is one of the more commonly-spoken languages in sub-Saharan Africa, and serves mainly as a shared language
802     * that is often learned after becoming fluent in one of many other (vaguely-similar) languages of the area. An
803     * example sentence in Swahili, that this might try to imitate aesthetically, is "Mtoto mdogo amekisoma," meaning
804     * "The small child reads it" (where it is a book). A notable language feature used here is the redoubling of words,
805     * which is used in Swahili to emphasize or alter the meaning of the doubled word; here, it always repeats exactly
806     * and can't make minor changes like a real language might. This generates things like "gata-gata", "hapi-hapi", and
807     * "mimamzu-mimamzu", always separating with a hyphen here.
808     * <br>
809     * As an aside, please try to avoid the ugly stereotypes that fantasy media often assigns to speakers of African-like
810     * languages when using this or any of the generators. Many fantasy tropes come from older literature written with
811     * major cultural biases, and real-world cultural elements can be much more interesting to players than yet another
812     * depiction of a "jungle savage" with stereotypical traits. Consider drawing from existing lists of real-world
813     * technological discoveries, like https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_Africa , for
814     * inspiration when world-building; though some groups may not have developed agriculture by early medieval times,
815     * their neighbors may be working iron and studying astronomy just a short distance away.
816     * <br>
817     * Kondueyu; ma mpiyamdabota mise-mise nizakwaja alamsa amja, homa nkajupomba.
818     */
819    public static final FakeLanguageGen SWAHILI = swahili().register("Swahili");

867     * associated with the text. One early comment this received was, "it looks like a bunch of letters semi-randomly
868     * thrown together", which is probably a typical response (the comment was made by someone fluent in German and

871     * Libor cat naqoxekh dhuugad gisiqir?
872     */

1230    /**
1231     * Imitation Hindi, romanized to use the Latin alphabet using accented glyphs similar to the IAST standard.
1232     * Most fonts do not support the glyphs that IAST-standard romanization of Hindi needs, so this uses alternate
1233     * glyphs from at most Latin Extended-A. Relative to the IAST standard, the glyphs {@code "ṛṝḷḹḍṭṅṇṣṃḥ"} become
1234     * {@code "ŗŕļĺđţńņşĕĭ"}, with the nth glyph in the first string being substituted with the nth glyph in the second
1235     * string. You may want to get a variant on this language with {@link #removeAccents()} if you can't display the
1236     * less-commonly-supported glyphs {@code āīūĕĭáíúóŗŕļţĺđńñņśş}. For some time SquidLib had a separate version of
1237     * imitation Hindi that was accurate to the IAST standard, but this version is more usable because font support is
1238     * much better for the glyphs it uses, so the IAST kind was removed (it added quite a bit of code for something that
1239     * was mostly unusable).
1240     * <br>
1241     * Darvāga yar; ghađhinopŕauka āĕrdur, conśaigaijo śabhodhaĕđū jiviđaudu.
1242     */
1243    public static final FakeLanguageGen HINDI_ROMANIZED = hindi().register("Hindi Romanized");

1284    /**
1285     * Imitation Arabic, using mostly the Latin alphabet but with some Greek letters for tough transliteration topics.
1286     * It's hard to think of a more different (widely-spoken) language to romanize than Arabic. Written Arabic does not
1287     * ordinarily use vowels (the writing system is called an abjad, in contrast to an alphabet), and it has more than a
1288     * few sounds that are very different from those in English. This version, because of limited support in fonts and
1289     * the need for separate words to be distinguishable with regular expressions, uses somewhat-accurate digraphs or
1290     * trigraphs instead of the many accented glyphs (not necessarily supported by most fonts) in most romanizations of
1291     * Arabic, and this scheme uses no characters from outside ASCII.
1292     * <br>
1293     * Please try to be culturally-sensitive about how you use this generator. Classical Arabic (the variant that
1294     * normally marks vowels explicitly and is used to write the Qur'an) has deep religious significance in Islam, and
1295     * if you machine-generate text that (probably) isn't valid Arabic, but claim that it is real, or that it has
1296     * meaning when it actually doesn't, that would be an improper usage of what this generator is meant to do. In a
1297     * fantasy setting, you can easily confirm that the language is fictional and any overlap is coincidental; an
1298     * example of imitation Arabic in use is the Dungeons and Dragons setting, Al-Qadim, which according to one account
1299     * sounds similar to a word in real Arabic (that does not mean anything like what the designer was aiming for). In a
1300     * historical setting, FakeLanguageGen is probably "too fake" to make a viable imitation for any language, and may
1301     * just sound insulting if portrayed as realistic. You may want to mix ARABIC_ROMANIZED with a very different kind
1302     * of language, like GREEK_ROMANIZED or RUSSIAN_AUTHENTIC, to emphasize that this is not a real-world language.
1303     * <br>
1304     * Hiijakki al-aafusiib rihit, ibn-ullukh aj shwisari!
1305     */
1306    public static final FakeLanguageGen ARABIC_ROMANIZED = arabic().register("Arabic Romanized");
1307

1388    /**
1389     * Somewhat close to Old Norse, which is itself very close to Icelandic, so this uses Icelandic spelling rules. Not
1390     * to be confused with the language(s) of Norway, where the Norwegian languages are called norsk, and are further
1391     * distinguished into Bokmål and Nynorsk. This should not be likely to seem like any form of Norwegian, since it
1392     * doesn't have the a-with-ring letter 'å' and has the letters eth ('Ðð') and thorn ('Þþ'). If you want to remove
1393     * any letters not present on a US-ASCII keyboard, you can use {@link Modifier#SIMPLIFY_NORSE} on this language or
1394     * some mix of this with other languages; it also changes some of the usage of "j" where it means the English "y"
1395     * sound, making "fjord" into "fyord", which is closer to familiar uses from East Asia like "Tokyo" and "Pyongyang".
1396     * You can also now use {@link #NORSE_SIMPLIFIED} directly, which is probably easiest.
1397     * <br>
1398     * Leyrk tjör stomri kna snó æd ðrépdápá, prygso?
1399     */
1400    public static final FakeLanguageGen NORSE = norse().register("Norse");

1671     * to emulate or worship similar groups. The tendency here is for DEMONIC to be the language used by creatures that
1672     * are considered evil because of their violence, while INFERNAL is the language used by creatures that are
1673     * considered evil because of their manipulation and deceit (DEMONIC being "chaotic evil" and INFERNAL being "lawful
1674     * evil"). The name INFERNAL refers to Dante's Inferno and the various naming conventions used for residents of Hell
1675     * in the more-modern Christian traditions (as well as some of the stylistic conventions of Old Testament figures
1676     * described as false idols, such as Moloch and Mammon). In an effort to make this distinct from the general style
1677     * of names used in ancient Hebrew (since this is specifically meant for the names of villains as opposed to normal
1678     * humans), we add in vowel splits as used in LOVECRAFT and DEMONIC, then add quite a few accented vowels. These
1679     * traits make the language especially well-suited for "deal with the Devil" written bargains, where a single accent
1680     * placed incorrectly could change the meaning of a contract and provide a way for a fiend to gain leverage.
1681     * <br>
1682     * Zézîzûth eke'iez áhìphon; úhiah îbbëphéh haîtemheû esmez...
1683     */
1684    public static final FakeLanguageGen INFERNAL = infernal().register("Infernal");

1847    /**
1848     * Imitation text from an approximation of Korean, using the Revised Romanization method that is official in South
1849     * Korea today and is easier to type. The text this makes may be hard to pronounce. Korean is interesting as a
1850     * language to imitate for a number of reasons; many of the sounds in it are rarely found elsewhere, it can cluster
1851     * consonants rather tightly (most languages don't; English does to a similar degree but Japanese hardly has any
1852     * groups of consonants), and there are many more vowel sounds without using tones (here, two or three letters are
1853     * used for a vowel, where the first can be y or w and the rest can be a, e, i, o, or u in some combination). Some
1854     * letter combinations possible here are impossible or very rare in correctly-Romanized actual Korean, such as the
1855     * rare occurrence of a single 'l' before a vowel (it normally only appears in Romanized text before a consonant or
1856     * at the end of a word).
1857     * <br>
1858     * Hyeop euryam, sonyon muk tyeok aengyankeon, koelgwaelmwak.
1859     */
1860    public static final FakeLanguageGen KOREAN_ROMANIZED = korean().register("Korean Romanized");

2078     * Fantasy/sci-fi language that could be spoken by some very-non-human culture that would typically be fitting for
2079     * an alien species. This alien language is meant to have an abrupt change mid-word for many words, with the suffix

2175     */

2178    /**
2179     * Fantasy language based closely on {@link #DRAGON}, but with much shorter words normally and closing syllables
2180     * that may sound "rushed" or "crude", though it has the same general frequency of most consonants and vowels.
2181     * This means it still uses lots of "t", "k", and "r", can group two vowels sometimes, and when there's a consonant
2182     * in the middle of a word, it is often accompanied by an "r" on one or both sides. If used with
2183     * {@link NaturalLanguageCipher}, this will look very similar to DRAGON, because the syllable lengths aren't
2184     * determined by this object but by the text being ciphered. Still, the ends of words are often different. It is
2185     * called KOBOLD because, even though the original kobold myth was that of a goblin-like spirit that haunted cobalt
2186     * mines, the modern RPG treatment of kobolds frequently describes them as worshippers of dragons or in some way
2187     * created by dragons, but generally they're a sort of failure to live up to a dragon's high expectations. The feel
2188     * of this language is meant to be something like a dragon's speech, but much less "fancy" and rather curt.
2189     * <br>
2190     * Thritriz, laazak gruz kokak thon lut...
2191     */
2192    public static final FakeLanguageGen KOBOLD = new FakeLanguageGen(
2193            DRAGON.openingVowels, DRAGON.midVowels, DRAGON.openingConsonants, DRAGON.midConsonants, DRAGON.closingConsonants,
2194            new String[]{"ik", "ak", "ek", "at", "it", "ik", "ak", "ek", "at", "it", "ik", "ak", "ek", "at", "it", "et", "ut", "ark", "irk", "erk"},
2195            DRAGON.vowelSplitters, new int[]{1, 2, 3}, new double[]{5, 11, 1},
2196            0.1, 0.0, 0.0, 0.22, genericSanityChecks, true).register("Kobold");

2400    /**
2401     * Fantasy/sci-fi language that would potentially be fitting for a trade language spoken by various very-different
2402     * groups, such as creatures with tentacled faces who need to communicate with spider-elves and living crystals.
2403     * This language tries to use relatively few sounds so vocally-restricted species can speak it or approximate it,
2404     * but some of its sounds are uncommon. It uses "ng" as Vietnamese does, as a sound that can be approximated with
2405     * "w" but more accurately is like the sound at the end of "gong". It uses a breathy sound in many vowels,
2406     * represented by "h", and this is separate from (and can be combined with) lengthening the vowel by doubling it
2407     * ("a", "ah", "aa", and "aah" are different). The "x" sound can be approximated by any of the "kh" or "q" sounds
2408     * used in various human languages, or with its usage in English for "ks". This does separate some vowels with "'",
2409     * which can be a glottal stop as in Hawaiian or various other languages, or approximated with a brief pause.
2410     * <br>
2411     * Zrolmolurz, voluu, nguu yuh'ongohng!
2412     */
2413    public static final FakeLanguageGen DEEP_SPEECH = deepSpeech().register("Deep Speech");
2414    /**
2415     * Somewhat close to Old Norse, which is itself very close to Icelandic, but changed to avoid letters not on a
2416     * US-ASCII keyboard. Not to be confused with the language(s) of Norway, where the Norwegian languages are called
2417     * norsk, and are further distinguished into Bokmål and Nynorsk. This just applies {@link Modifier#SIMPLIFY_NORSE}
2418     * to {@link #NORSE}. This replaces eth ('Ðð') and thorn ('Þþ') with 'th' unless preceded by 's' (where 'sð' or 'sþ'
2419     * becomes "st") or followed by 'r' (where 'ðr' or 'þr' becomes 'fr'). It replaces 'Æ' or 'æ' with 'Ae' or 'ae', and
2420     * replaces 'Ö' or 'ö' with 'Ou' or "ou", which can change the length of a String relative to NORSE. It removes all
2421     * other accent marks (since the two-dot umlaut accent has already been changed, this only affects acute accents).
2422     * It also changes some of the usage of "j" where it means the English "y" sound, making "fjord" into "fyord", which
2423     * is closer to familiar uses from East Asia like "Tokyo" and "Pyongyang".
2424     * <br>
2425     * Leyrk tyour stomri kna sno aed frepdapa, prygso?
2426     */
2427    public static final FakeLanguageGen NORSE_SIMPLIFIED = norse().addModifiers(Modifier.SIMPLIFY_NORSE)
2428            .register("Norse Simplified");
2429

2470    /**

2472     * one real-world language. It is meant to have a mix of hard and flowing sounds, roughly like Hebrew or Turkish,
2473     * but with a very different set of consonants and consonant blends. Importantly, consonant sounds are always paired
2474     * here except for the final consonant of a word, which is always one consonant sound if it is used at all. The
2475     * choices of consonant sounds are designed to be unusual, like "hl", "pkh", and "zhg" (which can all start a word).
2476     * <br>
2477     * Nyep khruv kwolbik psesh klulzhanbik psahzahwuth bluryup; hnish zhrim?
2478     */

2583    /**
2584     * A rough imitation of the Crow language of the American Midwest, using some tone marks. Some of the orthography
2585     * rules aren't clear across Internet information about the language, so this really is a "fake" language it will be
2586     * generating, not the real thing at all. This considers 'x' to be the rough back-of-throat noise that isn't in
2587     * English other than in loanwords, like the Scottish "loch," and in names like the German "Bach." Doubled (to use
2588     * the linguistic term, geminated) consonants are pronounced for a longer time, and doubled vowels with the same
2589     * accent mark or no accent mark are also lengthened. An un-accented vowel has a normal tone, an accented vowel has
2590     * a high tone, and an accented vowel followed by an un-accented vowel has a falling tone. This last feature is the
2591     * least common among languages here, and is a good way of distinguishing imitation Crow from other languages.
2592     * <br>
2593     * Pashu-umíkiki; chinébúlu ak kóokutú shu-eníí-a ipíimúu heekokáakoku?
2594     */
2595    public static final FakeLanguageGen CROW = crow().register("Crow");

3033    /**
3034     * A very rough imitation of the Vietnamese language, without using the accurate characters Vietnamese really uses
3035     * but that are rare in fonts. Since so many letters in correct Vietnamese aren't available in most fonts, this
3036     * can't represent most of the accented vowels in the language, but it tries, with 6 accents for each of a, e, i, o,
3037     * and u, though none for y. It also uses 'ð' from Icelandic in place of the correct d with bar. This could also
3038     * maybe be used as an approximation of (badly) Romanized Thai, since Thai normally uses its own script but also has
3039     * many tones (which would be indicated by the accents here).
3040     * <br>
3041     * Bach trich, nŏ ngiukh nga cä tran ngonh... 
3042     */
3043    public static final FakeLanguageGen VIETNAMESE = vietnamese().register("Vietnamese");

3101    /**
3102     * An imitation of Classical Latin, using some modern conventions so it can be suitable for scientific names or
3103     * other common English uses of Latin words. This tries to avoid the Latin letters that were mostly used for Greek
3104     * loanwords. You may want to capitalize these letters if they represent written ancient text, since Latin from the
3105     * Classical period didn't use lower-case letters.
3106     * <br>
3107     * Eisunt re ennius gin, vi.
3108     */
3109    public static final FakeLanguageGen LATIN = latin().register("Latin");
3110
3111    /**
3112     * An array that stores all the hand-made FakeLanguageGen constants; it does not store randomly-generated languages
3113     * nor does it store modifications or mixes of languages. The order these are stored in is related to the numeric
3114     * codes for languages in the {@link #serializeToString()} output, but neither is dependent on the other if this
3115     * array is changed for some reason (which is not recommended, but not out of the question). If this is modified,
3116     * then it is probably a bad idea to assign null to any elements in registered; special care is taken to avoid null
3117     * elements in its original state, so some code may rely on the items being usable and non-null.
3118     */
3119    public static final FakeLanguageGen[] registered;
3120    public static final String[] registeredNames;
3121    static {
3122        // the first item in registry is null so it can be a placeholder for random languages; we want to skip it.
3123        registered = new FakeLanguageGen[registry.size()-1];
3124        registeredNames = new String[registered.length];
3125        for (int i = 0; i < registered.length; i++) {
3126            registeredNames[i] = registry.keyAt(i+1);
3127            registered[i] = registry.getAt(i+1);
3128        }
3129    }
3130
3131    /**
3132     * If a FakeLanguageGen is known and is in {@link #registered}, this allows you to look up that FakeLanguageGen by
3133     * name (using a name from {@link #registeredNames}).
3134     * @param name a String name such as "English", "Korean Romanized", or "Russian Authentic"
3135     * @return a FakeLanguageGen corresponding to the given name, or null if none was found
3136     */
3137    public static FakeLanguageGen get(String name)
3138    {
3139        return registry.get(name);
3140    }
3141    /**
3142     * If a FakeLanguageGen is known and is in {@link #registered}, this allows you to look up that FakeLanguageGen by
3143     * index, from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registered.length - 1}.
3144     * @param index an int from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registered.length - 1}
3145     * @return a FakeLanguageGen corresponding to the given index, or null if none was found
3146     */
3147    public static FakeLanguageGen getAt(int index)
3148    {
3149        return registry.getAt(index);
3150    }
3151    /**
3152     * If a FakeLanguageGen is known and is in {@link #registered}, this allows you to look up that FakeLanguageGen's
3153     * name by index, from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length - 1}.
3154     * @param index an int from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length - 1}
3155     * @return a FakeLanguageGen corresponding to the given index, or null if none was found
3156     */
3157    public static String nameAt(int index)
3158    {
3159        return registry.keyAt(index);
3160    }

3219    /**
3220     * This is a very complicated constructor! Maybe look at the calls to this to initialize static members of this
3221     * class, such as LOVECRAFT and GREEK_ROMANIZED in the source code.
3222     *
3223     * @param openingVowels        String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear at the start
3224     *                             of a word or in the middle; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3225     * @param midVowels            String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear in the
3226     *                             middle of the word; all openingVowels are automatically copied into this internally.
3227     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
3228     * @param openingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster that can appear
3229     *                             at the start of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3230     * @param midConsonants        String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
3231     *                             between vowels; all closingConsonants are automatically copied into this internally.
3232     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
3233     * @param closingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
3234     *                             at the end of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3235     * @param closingSyllables     String array where each element is a syllable starting with a vowel and ending in
3236     *                             whatever the word should end in; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3237     * @param vowelSplitters       String array where each element is a mark that goes between vowels, so if "-" is in this,
3238     *                             then "a-a" may be possible; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3239     * @param syllableLengths      int array where each element is a possible number of syllables a word can use; closely
3240     *                             tied to syllableFrequencies
3241     * @param syllableFrequencies  double array where each element corresponds to an element in syllableLengths and
3242     *                             represents how often each syllable count should appear relative to other counts; there
3243     *                             is no need to restrict the numbers to add up to any other number
3244     * @param vowelStartFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words start with vowels;
3245     *                             higher numbers yield more words starting with vowels
3246     * @param vowelEndFrequency    a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words end with vowels; higher
3247     *                             numbers yield more words ending in vowels
3248     * @param vowelSplitFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that, if vowelSplitters is not empty, determines how
3249     *                             often a vowel will be split into two vowels separated by one of those splitters
3250     * @param syllableEndFrequency a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often an element of
3251     *                             closingSyllables is used instead of ending normally
3252     */
3253    public FakeLanguageGen(String[] openingVowels, String[] midVowels, String[] openingConsonants,
3254                           String[] midConsonants, String[] closingConsonants, String[] closingSyllables, String[] vowelSplitters,
3255                           int[] syllableLengths, double[] syllableFrequencies, double vowelStartFrequency,
3256                           double vowelEndFrequency, double vowelSplitFrequency, double syllableEndFrequency) {
3257        this(openingVowels, midVowels, openingConsonants, midConsonants, closingConsonants, closingSyllables,
3258                vowelSplitters, syllableLengths, syllableFrequencies, vowelStartFrequency, vowelEndFrequency,
3259                vowelSplitFrequency, syllableEndFrequency, englishSanityChecks, true);
3260    }

3262    /**
3263     * This is a very complicated constructor! Maybe look at the calls to this to initialize static members of this
3264     * class, such as LOVECRAFT and GREEK_ROMANIZED in the source code.
3265     *
3266     * @param openingVowels        String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear at the start
3267     *                             of a word or in the middle; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3268     * @param midVowels            String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear in the
3269     *                             middle of the word; all openingVowels are automatically copied into this internally.
3270     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
3271     * @param openingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster that can appear
3272     *                             at the start of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3273     * @param midConsonants        String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
3274     *                             between vowels; all closingConsonants are automatically copied into this internally.
3275     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
3276     * @param closingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
3277     *                             at the end of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3278     * @param closingSyllables     String array where each element is a syllable starting with a vowel and ending in
3279     *                             whatever the word should end in; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3280     * @param vowelSplitters       String array where each element is a mark that goes between vowels, so if "-" is in this,
3281     *                             then "a-a" may be possible; elements may be repeated to make them more common
3282     * @param syllableLengths      int array where each element is a possible number of syllables a word can use; closely
3283     *                             tied to syllableFrequencies
3284     * @param syllableFrequencies  double array where each element corresponds to an element in syllableLengths and
3285     *                             represents how often each syllable count should appear relative to other counts; there
3286     *                             is no need to restrict the numbers to add up to any other number
3287     * @param vowelStartFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words start with vowels;
3288     *                             higher numbers yield more words starting with vowels
3289     * @param vowelEndFrequency    a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words end with vowels; higher
3290     *                             numbers yield more words ending in vowels
3291     * @param vowelSplitFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that, if vowelSplitters is not empty, determines how
3292     *                             often a vowel will be split into two vowels separated by one of those splitters
3293     * @param syllableEndFrequency a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often an element of
3294     *                             closingSyllables is used instead of ending normally
3295     * @param sane                 true to perform sanity checks for pronounce-able sounds to most English speakers, replacing many
3296     *                             words that are impossible to say; slows down generation slightly, irrelevant for non-Latin alphabets
3297     * @param clean                true to perform vulgarity/obscenity checks on the word, replacing it if it is too close to a
3298     *                             common English vulgarity, obscenity, or slur/epithet; slows down generation slightly
3299     */
3300    public FakeLanguageGen(String[] openingVowels, String[] midVowels, String[] openingConsonants,
3301                           String[] midConsonants, String[] closingConsonants, String[] closingSyllables, String[] vowelSplitters,
3302                           int[] syllableLengths, double[] syllableFrequencies, double vowelStartFrequency,
3303                           double vowelEndFrequency, double vowelSplitFrequency, double syllableEndFrequency,
3304                           Pattern[] sane, boolean clean) {
3305        this.openingVowels = openingVowels;
3306        this.midVowels = new String[openingVowels.length + midVowels.length];
3307        System.arraycopy(midVowels, 0, this.midVowels, 0, midVowels.length);
3308        System.arraycopy(openingVowels, 0, this.midVowels, midVowels.length, openingVowels.length);
3309        this.openingConsonants = openingConsonants;
3310        this.midConsonants = new String[midConsonants.length + closingConsonants.length];
3311        System.arraycopy(midConsonants, 0, this.midConsonants, 0, midConsonants.length);
3312        System.arraycopy(closingConsonants, 0, this.midConsonants, midConsonants.length, closingConsonants.length);
3313        this.closingConsonants = closingConsonants;
3314        this.vowelSplitters = vowelSplitters;
3315        this.closingSyllables = closingSyllables;
3316
3317        this.syllableFrequencies = new double[syllableLengths[syllableLengths.length - 1]];
3318        double total = 0.0, bias = 0.0;
3319        for (int i = 0; i < syllableLengths.length; i++) {
3320            total += (this.syllableFrequencies[syllableLengths[i]-1] = syllableFrequencies[i]);
3321            bias += syllableLengths[i] * syllableFrequencies[i];
3322        }
3323        totalSyllableFrequency = total;
3324        syllableBias = bias / total;
3325        if (vowelStartFrequency > 1.0)
3326            this.vowelStartFrequency = 1.0 / vowelStartFrequency;
3327        else
3328            this.vowelStartFrequency = vowelStartFrequency;
3329        if (vowelEndFrequency > 1.0)
3330            this.vowelEndFrequency = 1.0 / vowelEndFrequency;
3331        else
3332            this.vowelEndFrequency = vowelEndFrequency;
3333        if (vowelSplitters.length == 0)
3334            this.vowelSplitFrequency = 0.0;
3335        else if (vowelSplitFrequency > 1.0)
3336            this.vowelSplitFrequency = 1.0 / vowelSplitFrequency;
3337        else
3338            this.vowelSplitFrequency = vowelSplitFrequency;
3339        if (closingSyllables.length == 0)
3340            this.syllableEndFrequency = 0.0;
3341        else if (syllableEndFrequency > 1.0)
3342            this.syllableEndFrequency = 1.0 / syllableEndFrequency;
3343        else
3344            this.syllableEndFrequency = syllableEndFrequency;
3345        this.clean = clean;
3346        sanityChecks = sane;
3347        modifiers = new ArrayList<>(4);
3348    }
3349
3350    private FakeLanguageGen(String[] openingVowels, String[] midVowels, String[] openingConsonants,
3351                            String[] midConsonants, String[] closingConsonants, String[] closingSyllables,
3352                            String[] vowelSplitters, double[] syllableFrequencies,
3353                            double vowelStartFrequency, double vowelEndFrequency, double vowelSplitFrequency,
3354                            double syllableEndFrequency, Pattern[] sanityChecks, boolean clean,
3355                            List<Modifier> modifiers) {
3356        this.openingVowels = copyStrings(openingVowels);
3357        this.midVowels = copyStrings(midVowels);
3358        this.openingConsonants = copyStrings(openingConsonants);
3359        this.midConsonants = copyStrings(midConsonants);
3360        this.closingConsonants = copyStrings(closingConsonants);
3361        this.closingSyllables = copyStrings(closingSyllables);
3362        this.vowelSplitters = copyStrings(vowelSplitters);
3363        this.syllableFrequencies = Arrays.copyOf(syllableFrequencies, syllableFrequencies.length);
3364        this.vowelStartFrequency = vowelStartFrequency;
3365        this.vowelEndFrequency = vowelEndFrequency;
3366        this.vowelSplitFrequency = vowelSplitFrequency;
3367        this.syllableEndFrequency = syllableEndFrequency;
3368        double total = 0.0, bias = 0.0;
3369        for (int i = 0; i < syllableFrequencies.length; i++) {
3370            total += syllableFrequencies[i];
3371            bias += (i + 1.0) * syllableFrequencies[i];
3372        }
3373        totalSyllableFrequency = total;
3374        syllableBias = bias / total;
3375        if (sanityChecks == null)
3376            this.sanityChecks = null;
3377        else {
3378            this.sanityChecks = new Pattern[sanityChecks.length];
3379            System.arraycopy(sanityChecks, 0, this.sanityChecks, 0, sanityChecks.length);
3380        }
3381        this.clean = clean;
3382        this.modifiers = new ArrayList<>(modifiers);
3383    }

3385    private static String[] processParts(OrderedMap<String, String> parts, Set<String> missingSounds,
3386                                         Set<String> forbidden, IRNG rng, double repeatSingleChance,
3387                                         int preferredLimit) {
3388        int l, sz = parts.size();
3389        List<String> working = new ArrayList<>(sz * 24);
3390        String pair;
3391        for (int e = 0; e < parts.size(); e++) {
3392            Map.Entry<String, String> sn = parts.entryAt(e);
3393            if (missingSounds.contains(sn.getKey()))
3394                continue;
3395            for (String t : sn.getValue().split(" ")) {
3396                if (forbidden.contains(t))
3397                    continue;
3398                l = t.length();
3399                int num;
3400                char c;
3401                switch (l) {
3402                    case 0:
3403                        break;
3404                    case 1:
3405                        working.add(t);
3406                        working.add(t);
3407                        working.add(t);
3408                        c = t.charAt(0);
3409                        num = 0;
3410                        boolean repeat = true;
3411                        switch (c) {
3412                            case 'w':
3413                                num += 2;
3414                            case 'y':
3415                            case 'h':
3416                                num += 4;
3417                            case 'q':
3418                            case 'x':
3419                                num += 4;
3420                                repeat = false;
3421                                break;
3422                            case 'i':
3423                            case 'u':
3424                                repeat = false;
3425                                num = 13;
3426                                break;
3427                            case 'z':
3428                            case 'v':
3429                                num = 4;
3430                                break;
3431                            case 'j':
3432                                num = 7;
3433                                break;
3434                            default:
3435                                if (e >= preferredLimit)
3436                                    num = 6;
3437                                else
3438                                    num = 13;
3439                        }
3440                        for (int i = 0; i < num * 3; i++) {
3441                            if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.75) {
3442                                working.add(t);
3443                            }
3444                        }
3445
3446                        if (repeat && rng.nextDouble() < repeatSingleChance) {
3447                            pair = t + t;
3448                            if (missingSounds.contains(pair))
3449                                continue;
3450                            working.add(pair);
3451                            working.add(pair);
3452                            working.add(pair);
3453                            if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.7) {
3454                                working.add(pair);
3455                                working.add(pair);
3456                            }
3457                            if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.7) {
3458                                working.add(pair);
3459                            }
3460                        }
3461
3462                        break;
3463                    case 2:
3464                        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.65) {
3465                            c = t.charAt(1);
3466                            switch (c) {
3467                                case 'z':
3468                                    num = 1;
3469                                    break;
3470                                case 'w':
3471                                    num = 3;
3472                                    break;
3473                                case 'n':
3474                                    num = 4;
3475                                    break;
3476                                default:
3477
3478                                    if (e >= preferredLimit)
3479                                        num = 2;
3480                                    else
3481                                        num = 7;
3482                            }
3483                            working.add(t);
3484                            for (int i = 0; i < num; i++) {
3485                                if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.25) {
3486                                    working.add(t);
3487                                }
3488                            }
3489                        }
3490                        break;
3491                    case 3:
3492                        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.5) {
3493                            c = t.charAt(0);
3494                            switch (c) {
3495                                case 'z':
3496                                    num = 1;
3497                                    break;
3498                                case 'w':
3499                                    num = 3;
3500                                    break;
3501                                case 'n':
3502                                    num = 4;
3503                                    break;
3504                                default:
3505                                    if (e >= preferredLimit)
3506                                        num = 2;
3507                                    else
3508                                        num = 6;
3509                            }
3510                            working.add(t);
3511                            for (int i = 0; i < num; i++) {
3512                                if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.2) {
3513                                    working.add(t);
3514                                }
3515                            }
3516                        }
3517                        break;
3518                    default:
3519                        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.3 && (t.charAt(l - 1) != 'z' || rng.nextDouble() < 0.1)) {
3520                            working.add(t);
3521                        }
3522                        break;
3523                }
3524            }
3525        }
3526        return working.toArray(new String[0]);
3527    }

3529    public static FakeLanguageGen randomLanguage(IRNG rng) {

3533    public static FakeLanguageGen randomLanguage(long seed) {
3534        GWTRNG rng = new GWTRNG(seed);
3535        int[] lengths = new int[rng.between(3, 5)];
3536        System.arraycopy(new int[]{1, 2, 3, 4}, 0, lengths, 0, lengths.length);
3537        double[] chances = new double[lengths.length];
3538        System.arraycopy(new double[]{
3539                5 + rng.nextDouble(4), 13 + rng.nextDouble(9), 3 + rng.nextDouble(3), 1 + rng.nextDouble(2)
3540        }, 0, chances, 0, chances.length);
3541        double vowelHeavy = rng.between(0.2, 0.5), removalRate = rng.between(0.15, 0.65);
3542        int sz = openCons.size();
3543        int[] reordering = rng.randomOrdering(sz), vOrd = rng.randomOrdering(openVowels.size());
3544        OrderedMap<String, String>
3545                parts0 = new OrderedMap<>(openVowels),
3546                parts1 = new OrderedMap<>(openCons),
3547                parts2 = new OrderedMap<>(midCons),
3548                parts3 = new OrderedMap<>(closeCons);
3549        OrderedSet<String> forbidden = new OrderedSet<>(1024, 0.25f), missingSounds = new OrderedSet<>(64, 0.875f);
3550        parts1.reorder(reordering);
3551        parts2.reorder(reordering);
3552        parts3.reorder(reordering);
3553        parts0.reorder(vOrd);
3554        int n;
3555
3556        int mn = Math.min(rng.nextInt(3), rng.nextInt(3)), sz0, p0s;
3557
3558        for (n = 0; n < mn; n++) {
3559            missingSounds.add(parts0.keyAt(0));
3560            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts0.getAt(0).split(" "));
3561            parts0.removeFirst();
3562        }
3563        p0s = parts0.size();
3564        sz0 = Math.max(rng.between(1, p0s + 1), rng.between(1, p0s + 1));
3565        char[] nextAccents = new char[sz0], unaccented = new char[sz0];
3566        int vowelAccent = rng.between(1, 7);
3567        for (int i = 0; i < sz0; i++) {
3568            nextAccents[i] = accentedVowels[vOrd[i + mn]][vowelAccent];
3569            unaccented[i] = accentedVowels[vOrd[i + mn]][0];
3570        }
3571        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.8) {
3572            for (int i = 0; i < sz0; i++) {
3573                char ac = nextAccents[i], ua = unaccented[i];
3574                String v = "", uas = String.valueOf(ua);
3575                Pattern pat = Pattern.compile("\\b([aeiou]*)(" + ua + ")([aeiou]*)\\b");
3576                Replacer rep = pat.replacer("$1$2$3 $1" + ac + "$3"), repLess = pat.replacer("$1" + ac + "$3");
3577                for (int j = 0; j < p0s; j++) {
3578                    String k = parts0.keyAt(j);
3579                    if (uas.equals(k)) // uas is never null, always length 1
3580                        v = parts0.getAt(j);
3581                    else {
3582                        String current = parts0.getAt(j);
3583                        String[] splits = current.split(" ");
3584                        for (int s = 0; s < splits.length; s++) {
3585                            if (forbidden.contains(uas) && splits[s].contains(uas))
3586                                forbidden.add(splits[s].replace(ua, ac));
3587                        }
3588                        parts0.put(k, rep.replace(current));
3589                    }
3590                }
3591                parts0.put(String.valueOf(ac), repLess.replace(v));
3592            }
3593        }
3594
3595        n = 0;
3596        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.75) {
3597            missingSounds.add("z");
3598            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("z").split(" "));
3599            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("z").split(" "));
3600            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("z").split(" "));
3601            n++;
3602        }
3603        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.82) {
3604            missingSounds.add("x");
3605            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("x").split(" "));
3606            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("x").split(" "));
3607            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("x").split(" "));
3608            n++;
3609        }
3610        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.92) {
3611            missingSounds.add("qu");
3612            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("qu").split(" "));
3613            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("qu").split(" "));
3614            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("qu").split(" "));
3615            n++;
3616        }
3617        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.96) {
3618            missingSounds.add("q");
3619            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("q").split(" "));
3620            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("q").split(" "));
3621            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("q").split(" "));
3622            n++;
3623        }
3624        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.97) {
3625            missingSounds.add("tl");
3626            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("tl").split(" "));
3627            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("tl").split(" "));
3628            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("tl").split(" "));
3629            n++;
3630        }
3631        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.86) {
3632            missingSounds.add("ph");
3633            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("ph").split(" "));
3634            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("ph").split(" "));
3635            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("ph").split(" "));
3636            n++;
3637        }
3638        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.94) {
3639            missingSounds.add("kh");
3640            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("kh").split(" "));
3641            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("kh").split(" "));
3642            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("kh").split(" "));
3643            n++;
3644        }
3645        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.96) {
3646            missingSounds.add("bh");
3647            missingSounds.add("dh");
3648            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("bh").split(" "));
3649            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("bh").split(" "));
3650            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("bh").split(" "));
3651            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("dh").split(" "));
3652            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("dh").split(" "));
3653            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("dh").split(" "));
3654            n++;
3655            n++;
3656        }
3657
3658        for (; n < sz * removalRate; n++) {
3659            missingSounds.add(parts1.keyAt(n));
3660            missingSounds.add(parts2.keyAt(n));
3661            missingSounds.add(parts3.keyAt(n));
3662            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.getAt(n).split(" "));
3663            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.getAt(n).split(" "));
3664            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.getAt(n).split(" "));
3665        }
3666
3667        return new FakeLanguageGen(
3668                processParts(parts0, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, 0.0, p0s),
3669                new String[]{},
3670                processParts(openCons, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, 0.0, 4096),
3671                processParts(midCons, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, (rng.nextDouble() * 3 - 0.75) * 0.4444, 4096),
3672                processParts(closeCons, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, (rng.nextDouble() * 3 - 0.75) * 0.2857, 4096),
3673                new String[]{},
3674                new String[]{}, lengths, chances, vowelHeavy, vowelHeavy * 1.8, 0.0, 0.0, genericSanityChecks, true).summarize("0#" + seed + "@1");
3675    }

3677    protected static boolean checkAll(CharSequence testing, Pattern[] checks) {
3678        CharSequence fixed = removeAccents(testing);
3679        for (int i = 0; i < checks.length; i++) {
3680            if (checks[i].matcher(fixed).find())
3681                return false;
3682        }
3683        return true;
3684    }
3685
3686    /**
3687     * Checks a CharSequence, such as a String, against an overzealous vulgarity filter, returning true if the text
3688     * could contain vulgar elements or words that could seem vulgar or juvenile. The idea here is that false positives
3689     * are OK as long as there are very few false negatives (missed vulgar words). Does not check punctuation or numbers
3690     * that could look like letters.
3691     * @param testing the text, as a CharSequence such as a String, to check
3692     * @return true if the text could contain a vulgar or juvenile element; false if it probably doesn't
3693     */
3694    public static boolean checkVulgarity(CharSequence testing)
3695    {
3696        CharSequence fixed = removeAccents(testing);
3697        for (int i = 0; i < vulgarChecks.length; i++) {
3698            if (vulgarChecks[i].matcher(fixed).find())
3699            {
3700//                System.out.println(vulgarChecks[i]);
3701                return true;
3702            }
3703        }
3704        return false;
3705    }

3707    /**
3708     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen, using and changing the current seed.
3709     *
3710     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3711     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3712     */
3713    public String word(boolean capitalize) {
3714        return word(srng, capitalize);
3715    }
3716
3717    /**
3718     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified long seed to use for a shared StatefulRNG.
3719     * If seed is the same, a FakeLanguageGen should produce the same word every time with this method.
3720     *
3721     * @param seed       the seed, as a long, to use for the randomized string building
3722     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3723     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3724     */
3725    public String word(long seed, boolean capitalize) {
3726        srng.setState(seed);
3727        return word(srng, capitalize);
3728    }
3729
3730    /**
3731     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified RNG.
3732     *
3733     * @param rng        the RNG to use for the randomized string building
3734     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3735     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3736     */
3737    public String word(IRNG rng, boolean capitalize) {
3738        while (true) {
3739            sb.setLength(0);
3740            ender.setLength(0);
3741
3742            double syllableChance = rng.nextDouble(totalSyllableFrequency);
3743            int syllables = 1, i = 0;
3744            for (int s = 0; s < syllableFrequencies.length; s++) {
3745                if(syllableChance < syllableFrequencies[s])
3746                {
3747                    syllables = s + 1;
3748                    break;
3749                } else
3750                {
3751                    syllableChance -= syllableFrequencies[s];
3752                }
3753            }
3754            if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelStartFrequency) {
3755                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3756                if (syllables == 1)
3757                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3758                else
3759                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3760                i++;
3761            } else {
3762                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingConsonants));
3763            }
3764            String close = "";
3765            boolean redouble = false;
3766            if (i < syllables) {
3767                if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3768                    close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3769                    if (close.contains("@") && (syllables & 1) == 0) {
3770                        redouble = true;
3771                        syllables >>= 1;
3772
3773                        //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3774                    }
3775                    if (!close.contains("@"))
3776                        ender.append(close);
3777                    else if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelEndFrequency) {
3778                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3779                        if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3780                            ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3781                                    .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3782                        }
3783                    }
3784                } else {
3785                    ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3786                    if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3787                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3788                                .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3789                    }
3790                    if (rng.nextDouble() >= vowelEndFrequency) {
3791                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3792                        if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3793                            close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3794                            if (close.contains("@") && (syllables & 1) == 0) {
3795                                redouble = true;
3796                                syllables >>= 1;
3797
3798                                //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3799                            }
3800                            if (!close.contains("@"))
3801                                ender.append(close);
3802                        }
3803                    }
3804                }
3805                i += vowelClusters.matcher(ender).findAll().count();
3806
3807            }
3808
3809            for (; i < syllables; i++) {
3810                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3811                if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3812                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3813                            .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3814                }
3815                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3816            }
3817
3818            sb.append(ender);
3819            if (redouble && i <= syllables + 1) {
3820                sb.append(close.replaceAll("@", sb.toString()));
3821            }
3822
3823            if (sanityChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, sanityChecks))
3824            {
3825                continue;
3826            }
3827
3828            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3829                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
3830            }
3831
3832            if (capitalize)
3833                sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
3834
3835            if (clean && !checkAll(sb, vulgarChecks))
3836            {
3837                continue;
3838            }
3839            return sb.toString();
3840        }
3841    }
3842
3843    /**
3844     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen with an approximate number of syllables using the specified long seed 
3845     * to use for a shared StatefulRNG.
3846     * If seed and the other parameters are the same, a FakeLanguageGen should produce the same word every time with
3847     * this method.
3848     *
3849     * @param seed       the seed, as a long, to use for the randomized string building
3850     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3851     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
3852     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3853     */
3854    public String word(long seed, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables) {
3855        srng.setState(seed);
3856        return word(srng, capitalize, approxSyllables);
3857    }

3870    /**
3871     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen with an approximate number of syllables using the specified long seed 
3872     * to use for a shared StatefulRNG. This takes an array of {@link Pattern} objects (from RegExodus, not
3873     * java.util.regex) that should match invalid outputs, such as words that shouldn't be generated in some context due
3874     * to vulgarity or cultural matters. If seed and the other parameters are the same, a FakeLanguageGen should produce
3875     * the same word every time with this method.
3876     *
3877     * @param seed       the seed, as a long, to use for the randomized string building
3878     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3879     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
3880     * @param additionalChecks an array of RegExodus Pattern objects that match invalid words (these may be additional vulgarity checks, for example)
3881     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3882     */
3883    public String word(long seed, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables, Pattern[] additionalChecks) {
3884        srng.setState(seed);
3885        return word(srng, capitalize, approxSyllables, additionalChecks);

3888    /**
3889     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified RNG with an approximate number of syllables.
3890     * This takes an array of {@link Pattern} objects (from RegExodus, not java.util.regex) that should match invalid
3891     * outputs, such as words that shouldn't be generated in some context due to vulgarity or cultural matters.
3892     *
3893     * @param rng        the RNG to use for the randomized string building
3894     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3895     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
3896     * @param additionalChecks an array of RegExodus Pattern objects that match invalid words (these may be additional vulgarity checks, for example)
3897     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3898     */
3899    public String word(IRNG rng, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables, Pattern[] additionalChecks) {
3900        if (approxSyllables <= 0) {
3901            sb.setLength(0);
3902            sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3903            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3904                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
3905            }
3906            if (capitalize) sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
3907            return sb.toString();
3908        }
3909        while (true) {
3910            sb.setLength(0);
3911            ender.setLength(0);
3912            int i = 0;
3913            if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelStartFrequency) {
3914                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3915                if (approxSyllables == 1 && closingConsonants.length > 0)
3916                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3917                else if (midConsonants.length > 0)
3918                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3919                i++;
3920            } else if (openingConsonants.length > 0) {
3921                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingConsonants));
3922            }
3923            String close = "";
3924            boolean redouble = false;
3925            if (i < approxSyllables) {
3926                if (closingSyllables.length > 0 && rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3927                    close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3928                    if (close.contains("@") && (approxSyllables & 1) == 0) {
3929                        redouble = true;
3930                        approxSyllables = approxSyllables >> 1;
3931
3932                        //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3933                    }
3934                    if (!close.contains("@"))
3935                        ender.append(close);
3936                    else if (redouble && rng.nextDouble() < vowelEndFrequency) {
3937                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3938                        if (vowelSplitters.length > 0 && rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3939                            ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3940                                    .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3941                        }
3942                    }
3943                } else {
3944                    ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3945                    if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3946                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3947                                .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3948                    }
3949                    if (rng.nextDouble() >= vowelEndFrequency) {
3950                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3951                        if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3952                            close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3953                            if (close.contains("@") && (approxSyllables & 1) == 0) {
3954                                redouble = true;
3955                                approxSyllables = approxSyllables >> 1;
3956
3957                                //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3958                            }
3959                            if (!close.contains("@"))
3960                                ender.append(close);
3961                        }
3962                    }
3963                }
3964                i += vowelClusters.matcher(ender).findAll().count();
3965            }
3966
3967            for (; i < approxSyllables; i++) {
3968                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3969                if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3970                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3971                            .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3972                }
3973                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3974            }
3975
3976            sb.append(ender);
3977            if (redouble && i <= approxSyllables + 1) {
3978                sb.append(close.replaceAll("@", sb.toString()));
3979            }
3980
3981            if (sanityChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, sanityChecks))
3982                continue;
3983
3984            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3985                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
3986            }
3987
3988            if (clean && !checkAll(sb, vulgarChecks))
3989                continue;
3990
3991            if (additionalChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, additionalChecks))
3992                continue;
3993
3994            if (capitalize)
3995                sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
3996
3997            return sb.toString();
3998        }
3999    }

4001    /**
4002     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified StatefulRNG with an approximate number of
4003     * syllables, potentially setting the state of rng mid-way through the word to another seed from {@code reseeds}
4004     * more than once if the word is long enough. This overload is less likely to be used very often.
4005     *
4006     * @param rng        the StatefulRNG to use for the randomized string building
4007     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
4008     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
4009     * @param reseeds an array or varargs of additional long seeds to seed {@code rng} with mid-generation 
4010     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
4011     */
4012    public String word(IStatefulRNG rng, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables, long... reseeds) {
4013        if (approxSyllables <= 0) {
4014            sb.setLength(0);
4015            sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
4016            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
4017                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
4018            }
4019            if (capitalize) sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
4020            return sb.toString();
4021        }
4022        int numSeeds, fraction = 1;
4023        if (reseeds != null)
4024            numSeeds = Math.min(reseeds.length, approxSyllables - 1);
4025        else numSeeds = 0;
4026        while (true) {
4027            sb.setLength(0);
4028            ender.setLength(0);
4029            int i = 0;
4030            if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelStartFrequency) {
4031                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
4032                if (approxSyllables == 1)
4033                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
4034                else
4035                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
4036                i++;
4037            } else {
4038                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingConsonants));
4039            }
4040            String close = "";
4041            boolean redouble = false;
4042            if (i < approxSyllables) {
4043                if (numSeeds > 0 && i > 0 && i == approxSyllables * fraction / (1 + numSeeds))
4044                    rng.setState(reseeds[fraction++ - 1]);
4045                if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
4046                    close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
4047                    if (close.contains("@") && (approxSyllables & 1) == 0) {
4048                        redouble = true;
4049                        approxSyllables = approxSyllables >> 1;
4050                    }
4051                    if (!close.contains("@"))
4052                        ender.append(close);
4053                    else if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelEndFrequency) {
4054                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
4055                        if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
4056                            ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
4057                                    .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
4058                        }
4059                    }
4060                } else {
4061                    ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
4062                    if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
4063                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
4064                                .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
4065                    }
4066                    if (rng.nextDouble() >= vowelEndFrequency) {
4067                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
4068                        if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
4069                            close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
4070                            if (close.contains("@") && (approxSyllables & 1) == 0) {
4071                                redouble = true;
4072                                approxSyllables = approxSyllables >> 1;
4073
4074                                //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
4075                            }
4076                            if (!close.contains("@"))
4077                                ender.append(close);
4078                        }
4079                    }
4080                }
4081                i += vowelClusters.matcher(ender).findAll().count();
4082            }
4083
4084            for (; i < approxSyllables; i++) {
4085                if (numSeeds > 0 && i > 0 && i == approxSyllables * fraction / (1 + numSeeds))
4086                    rng.setState(reseeds[fraction++ - 1]);
4087                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
4088                if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
4089                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
4090                            .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
4091                }
4092                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
4093            }
4094
4095            sb.append(ender);
4096            if (redouble && i <= approxSyllables + 1) {
4097                sb.append(close.replaceAll("@", sb.toString()));
4098            }
4099
4100            if (sanityChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, sanityChecks))
4101                continue;
4102
4103            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
4104                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
4105            }
4106
4107            if (capitalize)
4108                sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
4109
4110            if (clean && !checkAll(sb, vulgarChecks))
4111                continue;
4112            return sb.toString();
4113        }
4114    }
